item.title: Nintendo Expands Switch 2's GameCube Library With Another Game
item.content:encoded:
Fire Emblem is the first release of 2026

Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance was originally teased for the Switch Online + Expansion Pack's GameCube library last year, and it's now been added to the service in the first update of 2026.

This tactical role-playing game was originally released on the GameCube in 2005. We'll have a new review up soon on Nintendo Life, so look forward to that! For now, here's some backstory:

"All of Tellius is torn in a bloody war that has set the human empires against the nations of the shape-shifting laguz. A small band of mercenaries, led by the earnest but inexperienced Ike, possesses the means to end this war, but a hard path lies before them. Players must master strategy, steel and sorcery to restore order to the seven kingdoms."

To play this game via the Nintendo Classics - GameCube library, you'll need to have access to a Switch 2 and an active Switch Online + Expansion Pack membership.

As a bonus, Nintendo has also released the game's soundtrack on Nintendo Music. We've shared the full list of songs in a separate post.

This latest release for the GameCube library follows the addition of Wario's World in December. Some other titles planned for the service include Pok√©mon Colosseum and Super Mario Sunshine.

Will you be revisiting this game on the Switch 2? Let us know in the comments.

Liam is a news writer and reviewer across Hookshot Media. He's been writing about games for more than 15 years and is a lifelong fan of many iconic video game characters.

item.title: Xbox‚Äôs Towerborne is switching from a free-to-play game to a paid one
item.content:encoded:
Towerborne, a side-scrolling action RPG published by Xbox Game Studios that has been available in early access, will officially launch on February 26th. But instead of launching as a free-to-play, always-on online game as originally planned, Towerborne is instead going to be a paid game that you can play offline.

‚ÄúYou will own the complete experience permanently, with offline play and online co-op,‚Äù Trisha Stouffer, CEO and president of Towerborne developer Stoic, says in an Xbox Wire blog post. ‚ÄúThis change required deep structural rebuilding over the past year, transforming systems originally designed around constant connectivity. The result is a stronger, more accessible, and more player-friendly version of Towerborne ‚Äî one we‚Äôre incredibly proud to bring to launch.‚Äù

‚ÄúAfter listening to our community during Early Access and Game Preview, we learned players wanted a complete, polished experience without ongoing monetization mechanics,‚Äù according to an FAQ. ‚ÄúMoving to a premium model lets us deliver the full game upfront‚Äîno live-service grind, no pay-to-win systems‚Äîjust the best version of Towerborne.‚Äù

With the popular live service games like Fortnite and Roblox getting harder to usurp, Towerborne‚Äôs switch to a premium, offline-playable experience could make it more enticing for players who don‚Äôt want to jump into another time-sucking forever game. It makes Towerborne more appealing to me, at least.

With the 1.0 release of the game, Towerborne will have a ‚Äúcomplete‚Äù story, new bosses, and a ‚Äúreworked‚Äù difficulty system. You‚Äôll also be able to acquire all in-game cosmetics for free through gameplay, with ‚Äúno more cosmetic purchasing.‚Äù Players who are already part of early access will still be able to play the game.

Towerborne will launch on February 26th on Xbox Series X / S, Xbox on PC, Game Pass, Steam, and PS5. The standard edition will cost $24.99, while the deluxe edition will cost $29.99.

Follow topics and authors from this story to see more like this in your personalized homepage feed and to receive email updates.

  • Jay Peters

item.title: Towerborne Exiting Early Access, Coming To PS5 In February
item.content:encoded:
Towerborne, a Looter Brawler developed by Stoic and published by Xbox Games Studios, is leaving early access and launching as a full game on February 26, 2026. In addition to the Xbox platforms the game is currently available on, including PC, it will also be available on PlayStation 5. Along with the full launch, many changes are coming as part of the reimagined launch experience update.

Per Xbox, one of the major changes that current players may not be happy with is the game moving from free-to-play to a fully paid model. The game will start at $24.99 for the standard release and $29.99 for the more premium deluxe edition. However, one benefit of the new model is that the game will shift from always being online to a title players can buy once and play offline.

More of the Major Changes Coming to Towerborne 1.0 in February

In addition to the new paid release model, the game features multiple updates that enhance the player experience. For example, there‚Äôs an updated, complete story featuring a major antagonist, side quests, and an overhaul of the Bounty Board. There‚Äôs also a reworked difficulty system with a new Brutal difficulty for those seeking a truly challenging experience. Additionally, the Towerborne FAQ states that players can continue their character progression from Early Access; however, it recommends starting over and playing the game from the beginning.

During an interview as part of the New Game+ Showcase, game director Daniel McLaren and design director Shana Markham spoke about how important it was for them to listen to their player base and flesh out the story after it was originally intended for the narrative not to play a major role in the game and be more of a backdrop for the Looter Brawler experience.

Towerborne is currently available in Early Access for Xbox Game Pass subscribers, and Founder‚Äôs Packs can be purchased on PC via Steam.

For more news regarding Xbox games coming to PlayStation, learn more about Avowed‚Äôs impending release on Sony‚Äôs PlayStation 5.

Do you currently play Towerborne? Does it look like a game that you would be interested in? Sound off in our official Discord server. Also, don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves teases Fist of the North Star collaboration
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS4
  • PS5
  • Xbox Series

Kenshiro to join the fray?

SNK has released a short animated video teasing a collaboration between Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves and Fist of the North Star.

The video shows a boy and a girl about to be attacked by two thugs, before a mysterious person saves them using just his finger. The thugs are reminiscent of the villain characters in Fist of the North Star, and the finger-press sound is reminiscent of the pressure-point sound used in the anime. The mysterious character‚Äôs leg and arm also match the design of Kenshiro, the protagonist of Fist of the North Star.

SNK has previously posted similar animated teasers featuring Wolfgang Krauser (in English and Japanese), as well as Mr. Karate and Robert Garcia, so it is possible these animated trailers are intended to tease new downloadable characters for Season 2, which begins in January.

Fatal Fury: City of the Wolves is available now for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, PlayStation 4, and PC via Steam and Epic Games Store.

Watch the teaser below.
